B&P_Code_5536.1_5802_6735.title: Business & Professions Code — Licensed Professional Stamps and Signatures
B&P_Code_5536.1_5802_6735.requirement: B&P Code 5536.1 requires that civil engineering plans, specifications, reports, or documents be signed and stamped by a licensed civil engineer. B&P Code 5802 requires that licensed architects stamp and sign plans and specifications. B&P Code 6735 requires that licensed professional engineers stamp and sign engineering documents. Together, these require that all construction documents be stamped and signed by the respective licensed design professional (architect, civil engineer, or professional engineer) with the date of signing. Digital stamps/signatures must be noted as such on the plans.
B&P_Code_5536.1_5802_6735.key_thresholds: All final drawings and calculations must bear: (1) the stamp of the responsible licensed professional, (2) their original signature (wet or noted digital), and (3) the date of signing below the stamp. For B&P 5536.1 specifically, a wet signature is required on all plan sheets prepared by or under the supervision of the licensee.
B&P_Code_5536.1_5802_6735.adu_exceptions: No ADU-specific exceptions. Gov. Code 66314 does not exempt ADUs from professional licensing requirements. These are statewide professional practice requirements that apply to all construction projects regardless of building type. ADUs must comply with all applicable building codes per Gov. Code 66314(d)(8).
B&P_Code_5536.1_5802_6735.skill_reference_note: Not found in california-adu skill references. These are California Business & Professions Code requirements for professional licensing, not ADU-specific regulations. Verify against current B&P Code edition.

CPC_Table_702.1.title: California Plumbing Code Table 702.1 — Drainage Fixture Unit Values for Various Plumbing Fixtures
CPC_Table_702.1.requirement: CPC Table 702.1 assigns drainage fixture unit (DFU) values to each plumbing fixture type. These values determine the minimum waste line sizing required to serve the total fixture load. When adding an ADU with new plumbing fixtures (bathroom, kitchen sink, etc.), the total DFU count must be calculated for the combined primary dwelling + ADU to verify the existing building drain/sewer lateral is adequately sized. The 2nd review comment specifically requires: (1) showing the size of the existing waste line and justifying it for the increased DFU demand, (2) showing the existing water meter and supply line size and justifying adequacy for increased plumbing fixture demand, and (3) showing the point of connection.
CPC_Table_702.1.key_thresholds: Typical DFU values from CPC Table 702.1 include: water closet (toilet) = 4 DFU, bathtub/shower = 2 DFU, lavatory (bathroom sink) = 1 DFU, kitchen sink = 2 DFU, clothes washer = 3 DFU. Minimum building drain sizes: 3-inch drain handles up to 42 DFU; 4-inch drain handles up to 216 DFU. Exact values must be verified against the current edition of the CPC as adopted by the City of Placentia.
CPC_Table_702.1.adu_exceptions: Partial ADU exception exists for utility connections. Gov. Code 66324(d) states that converted ADUs under 66323(a)(1) cannot be required to install a new or separate utility connection (unless concurrent with new single-family construction). However, this project is a NEW DETACHED ADU, not a conversion — so Gov. Code 66324(e) applies: a new or separate connection directly from the utility to the ADU may be required. Gov. Code 66324(e) also requires that connection fees/capacity charges be proportionate to the ADU's burden, based on square footage or plumbing fixtures compared to the primary dwelling. None of this exempts the ADU from proper plumbing sizing — the DFU calculation itself is a building code requirement that applies fully.
CPC_Table_702.1.skill_reference_note: CPC Table 702.1 not found in california-adu skill references. The skill references mention plumbing fixtures only in the context of utility fee proportionality (Gov. Code 66324(e) in permit-fees.md and compliance-utilities.md). The actual DFU table values are in the California Plumbing Code (CPC), which is part of the California Building Standards Code (Title 24, Part 5). Verify fixture unit values against the current CPC edition as adopted locally.

ASCE_7-16_Section_30.11.title: ASCE 7-16 Minimum Design Loads — Section 30.11: Design Wind Loads on Open Buildings with Monoslope, Pitched, or Troughed Roofs (Component and Cladding)
ASCE_7-16_Section_30.11.requirement: ASCE 7-16 Section 30.11 provides the method for calculating component and cladding (C&C) wind pressures on open buildings and canopies (including covered patios, carports, and similar open or partially enclosed structures). The correction item requires updated wind calculations to verify that the covered landing patio is designed for C&C wind forces. This involves determining: (1) basic wind speed for the site (from ASCE 7-16 wind speed maps or local amendment), (2) exposure category, (3) effective wind area, (4) external pressure coefficients (GCp) from ASCE 7-16 Figure 30.11-1 through 30.11-7 depending on roof geometry, and (5) resulting design wind pressures on the patio roof components, connections, and cladding.
ASCE_7-16_Section_30.11.key_thresholds: Key parameters: Basic wind speed (V) varies by location and risk category — typical Southern California values are approximately 95-110 mph for Risk Category II (ASCE 7-16 Figure 26.5-1B). Exposure categories B (urban/suburban), C (open terrain), or D (coastal) affect velocity pressure. The section requires calculating net pressure coefficients for zones based on distance from edges and corners of the open roof. Brace angle, lag screw connections, and post sizes must be verified against these calculated wind loads.
ASCE_7-16_Section_30.11.adu_exceptions: No ADU-specific exceptions. Wind load design is a California Building Code requirement (CBC references ASCE 7 as the standard for determining wind loads). ADUs must comply with all applicable building codes per Gov. Code 66314(d)(8). There is no state ADU law provision that relaxes structural or wind load requirements for ADUs.
ASCE_7-16_Section_30.11.skill_reference_note: Not found in california-adu skill references. ASCE 7-16 is a referenced standard within the California Building Code (CBC/CRC) for structural design loads including wind. The california-adu skill covers ADU zoning and entitlement standards (Gov. Code 66310-66342) but does not cover building code structural requirements. Verify wind speed and exposure parameters against ASCE 7-16 as adopted by the 2022 CBC (or current local edition).

CRC_R302.1.title: California Residential Code R302.1 — Exterior Walls and Fire Separation Distance
CRC_R302.1.requirement: CRC R302.1 (Exterior Walls) establishes fire-resistance requirements for exterior walls, projections, and openings based on fire separation distance — the distance from the building face to the closest interior lot line, centerline of a street/alley, or imaginary line between two buildings on the same lot. For structures within 5 feet of a property line (or imaginary property line), the code requires: (1) exterior wall must have 1-hour fire-resistance rating on the exterior side, (2) projections (eaves, overhangs, covered patios) must have 1-hour fire-resistance protection on the underside if they project into the fire separation distance zone, and (3) openings (windows, doors) are generally not permitted or must be fire-rated assemblies. The correction specifically notes the covered landing patio is within 5 feet of the imaginary property line and requires 1-hour fire protection on the underside.
CRC_R302.1.key_thresholds: Fire separation distance < 3 feet: exterior wall must be 1-hour rated (both sides), no openings permitted, projections not permitted. Fire separation distance 3 feet to < 5 feet: exterior wall must be 1-hour rated (exterior side), openings limited to 25% of wall area with fire-rated assemblies, projections must be 1-hour rated on underside or not extend into the < 5-foot zone. Fire separation distance >= 5 feet: generally no additional fire resistance required for walls, though openings may still be limited up to 10 feet. Exact thresholds vary — verify against CRC R302.1 Table R302.1 as adopted by the local jurisdiction.
CRC_R302.1.adu_exceptions: ADU-specific fire sprinkler exception exists (Gov. Code 66314(d)(12)): fire sprinklers are required for an ADU only when required for the existing primary residence. However, CRC R302.1 fire separation requirements are NOT sprinkler requirements — they are exterior wall fire-resistance requirements and apply independently. The skill references note that 'all ADUs must still comply with applicable building code and health and safety requirements for dwellings, which may include fire access and safety provisions' (standards-fire.md). Additionally, the 4-foot maximum rear/side setback (Gov. Code 66314(d)(7)) means detached ADUs may frequently be within the 5-foot fire separation distance zone, making CRC R302.1 compliance a common issue for ADU projects. No ADU-specific exemption from CRC R302.1 fire-resistance requirements exists.
CRC_R302.1.skill_reference_note: CRC R302.1 is not directly cited in the california-adu skill references. However, the skill references establish the context: (1) standards-fire.md states all ADUs must comply with applicable building code and health and safety requirements including fire access and safety provisions; (2) standards-setbacks.md notes that a 4-foot maximum side/rear setback applies (Gov. Code 66314(d)(7)), which means ADUs are frequently within the 5-foot fire separation zone governed by CRC R302.1; (3) standards-setbacks.md also states that building or fire code requirements can justify additional standards (Gov. Code 66314(d)(8)). The actual fire-resistance rating tables and wall assembly requirements are in the California Residential Code (CRC), Title 24, Part 2.5. Verify against the current CRC edition as adopted locally.

Gov_Code_66314.title: Government Code 66314 — ADU Development Standards and Building Code Applicability
Gov_Code_66314.requirement: Gov. Code 66314 establishes the framework for ADU development standards. Subdivision (d)(8) is the key provision: ADUs must comply with all applicable local building codes and building standards. This means the California Building Standards Code (Title 24 — including the CBC, CRC, CPC, CEC, CMC, and all referenced standards like ASCE 7) applies fully to ADU construction. Subdivision (d)(12) provides the sole fire-related exception: fire sprinklers are required only when required for the existing primary residence.
Gov_Code_66314.key_thresholds: 66314(d)(7): 4-foot maximum side/rear setback. 66314(d)(8): full compliance with building codes required. 66314(d)(12): sprinklers only if required for primary residence. 66314(d)(4): attached ADU cannot exceed 50% of primary dwelling floor area.
Gov_Code_66314.adu_exceptions: The only building-code-level exception in 66314 is the sprinkler provision in (d)(12). All other building code requirements (structural, plumbing, fire separation, energy, etc.) apply without exception. Professional licensing requirements (B&P Code) are independent of ADU law entirely. The state ADU law is primarily focused on preventing overly restrictive ZONING standards — it does not relax building codes.
Gov_Code_66314.skill_reference_note: Found across multiple skill reference files. Key citations: standards-fire.md (sprinkler exception), standards-setbacks.md (4-foot setback and building code compliance), standards-solar.md (building code compliance), standards-height.md (building code compliance for two-story ADUs), zoning-nonconforming.md (all ADUs must comply with building codes), unit-types-adu-general.md (all applicable building, health and safety, and fire standards apply).

notes: None of the four specific code sections cited in the corrections (B&P Code 5536.1/5802/6735, CPC Table 702.1, ASCE 7-16 Section 30.11, CRC R302.1) appear directly in the california-adu skill reference files. This is expected — the skill references cover ADU ENTITLEMENT law (Government Code 66310-66342), which governs zoning, permitting process, and development standards. The cited code sections are BUILDING CODE requirements (professional licensing, plumbing sizing, structural wind loads, fire-resistance ratings) that apply to all residential construction, including ADUs. The bridge between them is Gov. Code 66314(d)(8), which confirms that ADUs must comply with all applicable building codes. The only ADU-specific exception relevant to these corrections is the fire sprinkler exception in Gov. Code 66314(d)(12), but that does NOT apply to CRC R302.1 fire separation (which is about wall/projection fire-resistance, not sprinkler systems). Notably, the 4-foot maximum rear setback (Gov. Code 66314(d)(7)) creates a common situation where detached ADUs are within the 5-foot fire separation distance of CRC R302.1, making the item 14 correction a frequent issue for ADU projects. For the 600 sq ft new detached ADU at 1232 N Jefferson St, Placentia: all four building code requirements apply without ADU-specific exceptions.
